data.meaning_mnemonic:
Things that are <kanji>beautiful</kanji> and <kanji>lovely</kanji> are very <vocabulary>beautiful</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>pretty</vocabulary>, and often <vocabulary>clean</vocabulary>, too. You can call someone <ja>綺麗</ja>. You can also mention how clean something is with <ja>綺麗</ja>. Gives you some insight as to what "beauty" is in Japan, I suppose. Take your baths, folks.

Wondering what the difference is between <ja>綺麗</ja> and <ja>美しい</ja>? <ja>美しい</ja> is more dramatic, so it implies you’re really blown away by something’s (or someone’s) beauty. <ja>綺麗</ja>, on the other hand, is a more everyday word that covers anything that’s beautiful, pretty, or even just clean. In other words, the bar is a bit lower for <ja>綺麗</ja>!

data.meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>acid</kanji> <kanji>element</kanji> is <vocabulary>oxygen</vocabulary>. In German it’s the same as in Japanese - it’s called “Sauerstoff”, including “sauer”, the word for “sour”. The noun version is “Säure” which means both “sourness” and “acid” (which again is the same in Japanese, the same kanji is used in both words). The word “oxygenium” in Greek/Latin literally means “acid maker”. Long ago chemists thought oxygen was a defining characteristic of acids, later they found out there are also acids without oxygen like hydrochloric/muriatic/salt acid and the defining characteristic actually is hydrogen. But the name stuck.

Or you could just imagine all the oxygen you breathe has turned into acid (oh no!), and it sucks to breathe. Whatever works for you.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji means <kanji>wound</kanji>, and this verb is transitive, so it means <vocabulary>to damage something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to injure something</vocabulary>.

You can use it to talk about parts of your body, so you'll sometimes see it used interchangeably with <ja>痛める</ja>. The difference is that it's objectively focussing on the damage, not the pain. That's why <ja>傷める</ja> can be used for objects like cars and furniture, too, whereas <ja>痛める</ja> is only for people and body parts.

You know you're not doing the dirtying, because it's <reading>rare</reading> (<ja>れる</ja>) for you to get anything dirty, though things do get dirty on their own.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Things seem <vocabulary>to get dirty</vocabulary> easily around here, which is why <reading>you go</reading> (<ja>よご</ja>) to great lengths to keep things clean.

Note that the reading <ja>よごれる</ja> is generally used for getting physically dirty, whereas <ja>けがれる</ja> is more figurative, so more like “to be defiled”.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>go beyond</kanji> so the verb vocab version is also <vocabulary>to go beyond</vocabulary>.

This is very similar in meaning to <ja>越える</ja>. Both can refer to overcoming some physical object or passing beyond a certain amount of time. However, <ja>越す</ja> tends to sound a little less intense, while <ja>越える</ja> really focuses on the physical or emotional challenge of overcoming a certain milestone. For example, while <ja>山を越す</ja> simply refers to crossing a mountain, <ja>山を越える</ja> gives the impression that crossing the mountain is a difficulty you've overcome.
data.reading_mnemonic:
The reading is the same as <ja>越える</ja>. So if you know that you know this too! In case you need a reminder, here's the mnemonic:

<vocabulary>To go beyond</vocabulary> <reading>child</reading> (<ja>こ</ja>) years in order to become an adult, you have to be 18 years old in the USA, and 20 years old in Japan.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fear</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to fear</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is shared with <ja>恐ろしい</ja>, which is "scary." Use that, and don't be afraid. You'll be able to learn this reading yet.

context_sentences.en: You can't move forward if you always fear failure.
context_sentences.ja: 失敗を恐れてばかりいては前に進めないよ。

context_sentences.en: I’m not afraid of anything except for going blind.
context_sentences.ja: 目が見えなくなること以外は、何も恐れることはないよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The word <ja>迷う</ja> means "to go astray" but this word is <vocabulary>to lead astray</vocabulary>. You are doing the astraying to someone or something else. You know this because the other person <reading>was</reading> (<ja>わす</ja>) just fine until you came along to lead them astray.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>迷う</ja>, so use that so you aren't lead astray too.

context_sentences.en: If you lead my daughter astray, I’ll never forgive you.
context_sentences.ja: もし俺の娘を路頭に迷わすようなことがあったら、一生許さないぞ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: 積もる is "to accumulate." Now you're doing the accumulating, and in order to do that you must go <vocabulary>to pile things up</vocabulary>. More and more and more. How do you know that this verb is when you're doing the accumulating? It's because you are piling up cows (<ja><reading>む</reading></ja>). Wow, a cow piler.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>積もる</ja>, so pile up your knowledge and remember it that way.

context_sentences.en: Now please grab a partner and begin loading the truck with turkey.
context_sentences.ja: それじゃあ2人組を作って、トラックに七面鳥を積み始めて下さい。

data.meaning_mnemonic: If <ja>主催</ja> is <kanji>sponsorship</kanji>, the verb version of that would be <vocabulary>to sponsor</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word <ja>主催</ja> already as well.

context_sentences.en: Our school is hosting a karaoke party this Saturday. Would you like to join us?
context_sentences.ja: うちの学校で土曜日にカラオケパーティーを主催するんだけど、よかったら来ない？

data.meaning_mnemonic: If <ja>催促</ja> is <kanji>urge</kanji>, then the verb version would be <vocabulary>to urge</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know <ja>催促</ja> first.

context_sentences.en: I’m sorry to be so demanding, but can you take some pictures of Tokyo Tower and send them to me by Monday, please? Thanks.
context_sentences.ja: 催促するようで申し訳ありませんが、東京タワーの写真を何枚か撮って月曜日までに送ってもらえませんでしょうか。

data.meaning_mnemonic: I don't know why a <kanji>mud</kanji> <kanji>pole</kanji> is a <vocabulary>robber</vocabulary>, but for some reason it is. Just imagine a robber covering himself in mud and standing behind a pole to hide, then jump out, then rob you of everything you've got.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is <ja>泥</ja> plus the reading for <ja>棒</ja> put together.

context_sentences.en: The training to become a burglar is as hard as boot camp.
context_sentences.ja: 泥棒になるためのトレーニングは、ブートキャンプ並にハードです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: It <kanji>resemble</kanji>s you! It <kanji>suit</kanji>s you! Wow, your good looks really cause this scarf <vocabulary>to suit</vocabulary> you, you know?
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is from <ja>似る</ja> and <ja>合う</ja>, put together.

context_sentences.en: I think a denim jacket would totally match your dress.
context_sentences.ja: そのワンピには絶対デニムのジャケットが似合うと思うよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember how <ja>驚く</ja> is "to be surprised"? This is when you are surprising someone else, doing the surprising, making this word <vocabulary>to surprise</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to shock</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>驚く</ja>. Don't be surprised if you remember the reading of this word because of your past knowledge.

context_sentences.en: The 23-year-old new recruit surprised everyone who works with him by marrying the 82-year-old CEO.
context_sentences.ja: 23歳の新入社員は82歳のCEOと結婚して、一緒に仕事をする人全員を驚かした。

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>掃除</ja> is <kanji>cleaning</kanji>, so the verb version would be <vocabulary>to clean</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, it'll help to know the word <ja>掃除</ja> as well.

context_sentences.en: "I’ve been awake since four this morning." "No way! What have you been doing?" "Well, just cleaning around the house."
context_sentences.ja: 「今朝は4時から起きてるよ。」「嘘でしょ？いったい何してるの？」「えっと…家を大掃除してるの。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>乾く</ja> is "to be dried." This is the version where you're doing the drying, making this <vocabulary>to dry something</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>乾く</ja>.

context_sentences.en: I love you so much. I need you. Could you please dry my wet shirts right now, Mr. Sun? Please!!!!
context_sentences.ja: あなたを愛しています。僕にはあなたが必要なんです。太陽さん、どうか僕の濡れたシャツを今すぐ乾かしてくれませんか？お願いします！！！

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>散る</ja> is "to be scattered." This is when you're doing the scattering. You know that because you're causing a <reading>ruckus</reading> (<ja>らかす</ja>) from all the scattering of money you're doing, down on the people below.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading of the <ja>散</ja> comes from <ja>散る</ja>. So, go ahead and scatter more memories around your brain, you got this already.

context_sentences.en: There are dirty clothes scattered all over the floor in my room. Even if I cleaned them up, it would just get messy again the next day.
context_sentences.ja: 私の部屋には脱ぎっぱなしの服が床に散らかっています。掃除しても、次の日にはまたすぐ散らかしちゃうんだよね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember how <ja>離れる</ja> is "to separate," where something is just separating and you're not doing the separating? Well, this one has the same meaning, but now you're doing the separating. This word is <ja>離す</ja>, and you know that you're doing the separating because if you don't, that person will <reading>sue</reading> (<ja>す</ja>) you for grabbing onto them and not letting go.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>離れる</ja>.

context_sentences.en: Sorry, I’m in the middle of something. I’ll call you back. Okay?
context_sentences.ja: ごめん。いま手が離せないんだ。後でかけ直してもいいかな？

data.meaning_mnemonic: If <ja>複数</ja> is <kanji>multiple</kanji>, and <ja>形</ja> is <kanji>shape</kanji>, then when something is in a "multiple shape," it has more than one version of itself. It's the <vocabulary>plural</vocabulary>, or the <vocabulary>plural form</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the word <ja>複数</ja> as well.

context_sentences.en: The plural of sheep is sheep.
context_sentences.ja: Sheepの複数形はsheepです。

context_sentences.en: My friend said, "You don't even know the plural of this word?" and laughed at me, and I was very hurt.
context_sentences.ja: 「この単語の複数形も知らないの？」って友達に笑われて、とても傷つきました。

context_sentences.en: In Japanese you don’t need to change things to the plural form as often as in English.
context_sentences.ja: 日本語では英語に比べて単語を複数形にすることは少ないです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you've <kanji>finish</kanji>ed <kanji>solv</kanji>ing something, you've come to a point of <vocabulary>comprehension</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>understanding</vocabulary>. Also, used in (often radio) communication to signify you know what's up. It's like saying "<vocabulary>roger</vocabulary>!"
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: He expressed his understanding with a weak nod and walked away.
context_sentences.ja: 彼は弱々しいうなずいて了解の意を示して、立ち去った。

data.meaning_mnemonic: This has a similar meaning to <ja>主人</ja> (<vocabulary>head of household</vocabulary>). You can remember it also as the meaning you learned with the kanji <ja>主</ja>, which is <vocabulary>master</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic:
The reading is of course different from what you learned with the kanji. Think of this:

The person who was your <vocabulary>head of household</vocabulary> was very strict. Anytime you did anything that was incorrect or bad, he/she would pull out the <reading>noose</reading> (<ja>ぬし</ja>), but would call it a "noosey" to be cute, since you were just a kid.

context_sentences.en: What is the name of the head of this household?
context_sentences.ja: この家の主の名前は何ですか。

context_sentences.en: I heard that the master of that castle doesn't have any heirs.
context_sentences.ja: あの城の主にはあとつぎがいないらしい。

context_sentences.en: It’s said that in this pond there is a huge leopard frog called the master of the old pond.
context_sentences.ja: この池には、古池の主と呼ばれる大きな殿様蛙がいると言われています。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Not to be confused with <ja>会社</ja>, which is a company, this is <vocabulary>society</vocabulary>. When a <kanji>company</kanji> <kanji>meet</kanji>s together, it's like a bunch of people, who are in groups, who come together to live in one world. That is a <vocabulary>society</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: Even if I leave home right now, I think I’ll probably be late for social studies.
context_sentences.ja: 今家を出ても、社会のじゅぎょうに間にあわないと思います。

context_sentences.en: As a member of the international society, I will not yield to food porn.
context_sentences.ja: 国さい社会の一員として、めしテロにはだんじてくっしません。

context_sentences.en: As a society, we need to be concerned about youths taking ’selfies’ at funerals.
context_sentences.ja: 社会問題として、若者がお葬式で自分撮りをすることについて考える必要がある。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>heart</kanji> <kanji>internal organs</kanji> is the <vocabulary>heart</vocabulary>, of course.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: I have a kind of telephone phobia and my heart starts beating very fast whenever I talk on the phone.
context_sentences.ja: 電話恐怖症みたいなのがあって、電話で話をする時に心臓がバクバクするんです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>lung</kanji> <kanji>internal organ</kanji> is the <vocabulary>lung</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: My grandfather died of inflammation of the lungs.
context_sentences.ja: 私の祖父は肺臓炎で亡くなりました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Inside</kanji> <kanji>internal organs</kanji> are your <vocabulary>internal organs</vocabulary>, though you'd think the second kanji would give a hint to that without the <ja>内</ja>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: They take the internal organs out of deer in my neighbor’s garage.
context_sentences.ja: ご近所さんのガレージで鹿の内臓を取り出すんです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>越す</ja> is "to go beyond." Now you're going beyond your home and <kanji>pull</kanji>ing everything with you to go to another home. You are trying <vocabulary>to move</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>to move homes</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings come from <ja>引く</ja> and <ja>越す</ja> put together. Careful of that <ja>っ</ja>.

context_sentences.en: "Dad, Fugu and I are getting married and moving to Japan." "Not while I’m alive, you won’t."
context_sentences.ja: 「パパ、フグと私、結婚して日本に引っ越すつもりよ。」「俺の目の黒いうちはそんなことはさせないぞ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>越す</ja> means "to go beyond." <ja>追</ja> is <kanji>follow</kanji>. If you are following someone, and then you go beyond them, you have overtaken them. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to overtake</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to surpass</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>追う</ja> and <ja>越す</ja> put together into one. You can overtake this word now that you know that.

context_sentences.en: I always wave my hand to say hi whenever I pass other bikers.
context_sentences.ja: 他の自転車走者を追い越す時、いつも挨拶代わりに手を振ります。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>祖父</ja> is grandfather and <ja>祖母</ja> is grandmother. This is both combined. Is it some hybrid grandmapa monster you've created in your lab? Hardly, it just refers to your <vocabulary>grandparents</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>祖父</ja> and <ja>祖母</ja>, which are exceptional readings on their own, so you'll need them in order to be able to read this one too.

context_sentences.en: My grandparents still see their pediatrician.
context_sentences.ja: 私の祖父母はまだ小児科医にかかっています。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that to <ja>飼う</ja> is "to keep a pet." If you're the <kanji>master</kanji> that is <kanji>keeping a pet</kanji> (<ja>飼う</ja>), then you are the <vocabulary>pet owner</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings for both. You'll need to remember the words <ja>飼う</ja> and <ja>主</ja> to be able to remember the reading of this word.

context_sentences.en: If a dog’s owner had chickenpox, could the dog get it too?
context_sentences.ja: もし犬の飼い主が水疱瘡になったら、その犬も水疱瘡になる可能性はあるんでしょうか。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember how <ja>傷</ja> is "wound"? Now a wound is <ja>つく</ja>ing to you, or in other words, is getting attached to you. If you get a wound attached to your body, you are probably going <vocabulary>to get hurt</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the word <ja>傷</ja>.

context_sentences.en: Aren’t I too young to be called a middle-aged woman? I’m hurt.
context_sentences.ja: おばちゃんって呼ばれる年齢かなあ。傷つくなあ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <ja>つける</ja> (attach) a <kanji>wound</kanji> to someone or something. In other words, this means <vocabulary>to hurt someone</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to scratch</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to damage</vocabulary> something.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is <ja>傷</ja>. If you remember the reading for that you got this too.

context_sentences.en: I might have scratched my contact lens.
context_sentences.ja: コンタクトレンズを傷つけちゃったかも。

context_sentences.en: We may also be hurting people without knowing it.
context_sentences.ja: 私たちも知らないうちに人を傷つけているかもしれません。

context_sentences.en: Who the heck damaged my Mercedes with an iron bar?! They'll pay for this!
context_sentences.ja: 誰だよ？俺のベンツに鉄棒で傷つけやがったのは？！見つけたらただじゃおかねえぞ！

data.meaning_mnemonic: After you <kanji>use</kanji> it you <kanji>throw away</kanji> it, making whatever it is you used a <vocabulary>disposable</vocabulary> item.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>使う</ja> and <ja>捨てる</ja>, combined into one.

context_sentences.en: For me, disposable pocket warmers are indispensable in winter.
context_sentences.ja: 私にとって、使い捨てカイロは冬には無くてはならないものです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>throw</kanji> and <kanji>throw away</kanji> something. That's why this means <vocabulary>to throw away</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>投げる</ja> and <ja>捨てる</ja>, combined into one garbage inducing dump of a word.

context_sentences.en: I threw my alarm clock away when it went off at six this morning.
context_sentences.ja: 今朝、六時に目覚ましがなった時に、その時計を投げ捨ててしまいました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>込む</ja> is "to be crowded." This, however, is when you make something crowded. How do you make something crowded? You have <vocabulary>to put in</vocabulary> more and more into the thing you want crowded until it is crowded. To do this act (which you are doing), you <reading>mail</reading> (<ja>める</ja>) things in over and over again. This will crowd the post office if I include all this mail in this mail box! Ha ha! What a rebel!
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>込む</ja>. No reading too crowded to include here.

context_sentences.en: I didn’t have enough time to load rounds into the shotgun.
context_sentences.ja: ショットガンに弾を込める時間がなかったんだ。

context_sentences.en: Put more emotion in your performance! Are you really a professional theatrical actor?
context_sentences.ja: もっと気持ちを込めて演技しろよ！それでもプロの劇団員か？

data.meaning_mnemonic: I would like to <kanji>say humbly</kanji> in this <kanji>crowded</kanji> place that I am going <vocabulary>to apply</vocabulary>. If there are a lot of other people applying, you feel humbled, so you say humbly you want to apply.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings come from <ja>申す</ja> and <ja>込む</ja>, stuck together... humbly.

context_sentences.en: I forgot to apply for the JLPT exam.
context_sentences.ja: JLPTのテストに申し込むのを忘れてしまった。

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>fly</kanji> into something <kanji>crowded</kanji> (say a moving train full of people) to die by <kanji>suicide</kanji> (<ja>自殺</ja>), that is going to be <vocabulary>suicide by train</vocabulary>. Unfortunately, this is a term you should probably be familiar with because it comes up from time to time on the news and around train stations. (Hopefully someday it will no longer be a term you need to know and we can remove it forever.)
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings come from <ja>飛ぶ</ja>, <ja>込む</ja>, and <ja>自殺</ja>. Combine them together to read this entire word.

context_sentences.en: He hooked up my PlayStation to his TV before leaving our house to commit suicide by jumping in front of a train. Do you think it means something?
context_sentences.ja: あいつ、飛び込み自殺をするために家を出る前、俺のプレイステーションをあいつのテレビに繋いだんだよな。何か意味があったのかな？

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>write</kanji> something on this paper but it is <kanji>crowded</kanji>. Why is it crowded? Because there are little boxes for you to write things in. You are filling out a form, which makes this verb <vocabulary>to fill out</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to write in</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>書く</ja> and <ja>込む</ja> combined into one.

context_sentences.en: You better hurry up and fill out an application. The office will close in ten minutes.
context_sentences.ja: 急いで申込書に書き込んだ方がいいよ。あと十分で事務所は閉まっちゃうんだから。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>込む</ja> means "to be crowded" so when you are crowded with people... well... you have a <vocabulary>crowd of people</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>人</ja> and <ja>込む</ja> combined together into one. Just keep in mind that the <ja>こ</ja> from <ja>込み</ja> changes to <ja>ご</ja> and you'll be fine.

context_sentences.en: I can't go into the middle of a crowd of people because I'm scared.
context_sentences.ja: 怖くて人込みの中に行けません。

context_sentences.en: When I walk inside Shinjuku Station, I always get frustrated with the crowds of people.
context_sentences.ja: 新宿駅構内を歩く時は、人込みでいつもイライラする。

context_sentences.en: They’re going to try kanchō me in the crowd. You guys are gonna protect me, right?
context_sentences.ja: あいつら、人込みに紛れて俺に浣腸しようとしてやがるんだ。お前らは俺を守ってくれるよなあ？

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun version of <ja>染</ja>. A dye would seem like the right answer, but what else is a dye? If you get it on you when you don't want to get it on you, it becomes a <vocabulary>stain</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is unlike what you learned with this kanji before. Just think about how you have this <vocabulary>stain</vocabulary> on your shirt, all because you were trying to dye some <reading>shee</reading>p (<ja>し</ja>) and they didn't like it. So now you have a big dye and sheep poo stain. How were you supposed to know sheep don't like being dyed?!

context_sentences.en: Couldn’t you find some way to remove this stain?
context_sentences.ja: この染みなんとか取れないかなあ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: If <ja>染める</ja> is "to dye," then this is <vocabulary>to be dyed</vocabulary>. You aren't doing the dying, because you know that if you did it you would have done things right, unlike the other person who dyed your hair. This person <reading>marr</reading>ed (<ja>まる</ja>) it up really bad.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as <ja>染める</ja>.

context_sentences.en: I’m worried that our kids will be tainted by this bad environment.
context_sentences.ja: 子供たちがこの悪い環境に染まってしまうことを心配してるのよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>汚れる</ja> is "to get dirty." This is when you make something dirty, aka "<vocabulary>to make dirty</vocabulary>." You know that this is the version where you make things dirty yourself because when you make someone dirty with all that poop you're flinging, they <reading>sue</reading> (<ja>す</ja>) you immediately. This happens a lot.
data.reading_mnemonic:
The reading comes from <ja>汚れる</ja>, so if you know that you can read this.

Note that the reading <ja>よごす</ja>  is generally used for making things physically dirty, whereas <ja>けがす</ja> means making someone or something impure in a figurative way.

context_sentences.en: We are out of clean bibs. Our baby boy got them all dirty.
context_sentences.ja: 綺麗なスタイが無くなっちゃった。うちの赤ちゃんが全部汚しちゃって。

context_sentences.en: He is a cunning man who never dirties his hands.
context_sentences.ja: アイツは自分では決して手を汚さない、ずるい男だ。

context_sentences.en: Terrible!!! I cannot tolerate it. It feels like a sacred place has been defiled.
context_sentences.ja: ひどい！許せません。神聖な場所を汚された気分です。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>say</kanji> a <kanji>reason</kanji> for your actions, but really it's just an <vocabulary>excuse</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is <ja>言う</ja> and <ja>訳</ja> combined.

You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What is most <vocabulary>valuable</vocabulary> to you? Of course it's your <reading>toe toe</reading> (<ja>とうと</ja>). It's your big toe (the long <ja>とう</ja>) with another small toe growing out of it (short <ja>と</ja>). Imagine your toe toe, and then imagine how valuable it is to you. So valuable! You can also think about <ja>尊い</ja>, a similar word which means "revered." It's a similar idea, and it has the same reading.

context_sentences.en: On saying that, Kuroda disappeared into the pleasure quarter.
context_sentences.ja: 黒田はそう言い残すと、歓楽街へと消えていった。

context_sentences.en: What does the tour of the pleasure quarter include?
context_sentences.ja: 歓楽街のツアーには何が含まれていますか。

context_sentences.en: I have traced the source of the rumour that I work in the pleasure quarter.
context_sentences.ja: 私が歓楽街で働いているという噂の源をつきとめました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: To do <kanji>loss</kanji> to something means you are doing something to make something have loss. This is <vocabulary>to harm</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to injure</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: In order <vocabulary>to harm</vocabulary> your opponent, you go way overboard. You <reading>soak</reading> (<ja>そこ</ja>) them in acid. Soaked head to toe. Too far man, too far.

context_sentences.en: I’m worried that you may ruin your health by working too hard.
context_sentences.ja: 働きすぎてあんたが健康を損なうんじゃないかって、心配してるのよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>loss</kanji> will give you a <vocabulary>disadvantage</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>handicap</vocabulary>. So, try not to get any losses... or you'll be at a disadvantage.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the kanji, so you aren't at a <vocabulary>disadvantage</vocabulary>... this time.

context_sentences.en: I had a loss of $500 in poker.
context_sentences.ja: ポーカーで五百ドル損をした。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Your <kanji>loss</kanji> comes from <kanji>damage</kanji> done to you. This is <vocabulary>damage</vocabulary>.

This word is usually used as a noun. It can occasionally be turned into verb by adding <ja>する</ja>, but this is very rare!
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: The truck crash damaged the cargo, but it was only minor damage.
context_sentences.ja: トラックの衝突で積荷がダメージを受けたが、小さな損害で済んだ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>loss</kanji> is a <vocabulary>heavy loss</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the <ja>おお</ja> reading of <ja>大</ja> coupled with the on'yomi reading for <ja>損</ja>. Just keep in mind that the <ja>そん</ja> changes to <ja>ぞん</ja> and you'll be good here.

context_sentences.en: I went to a pachinko parlor in the hopes of making a lot of money, but I ended up with a heavy loss instead.
context_sentences.ja: 大儲けするつもりでパチンコに行ったが、結局大損してしまった。

data.meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>all</kanji> <kanji>loss</kanji> is when you lose it all. It is a <vocabulary>total loss</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: If it turns out that the car is a total loss, many insurance companies will not pay the full repair cost.
context_sentences.ja: 車が全損してしまった場合、修理代は保険で全額支払われないことが多いです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're walking in the woods, when suddenly, a <vocabulary>branch</vocabulary> starts screaming at you, " <reading>Eh </reading>,  <reading>da </reading>d?" (<ja>えだ</ja>). The branch won't leave you alone, following you around while screaming "Eh, dad?", thinking you're its long-lost tree branch father. Poor thing.

context_sentences.en: The branches were bent by blood red apples.
context_sentences.ja: 枝は真っ赤な林檎でたわんでいた。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
data.reading_mnemonic: You want your <vocabulary>beans</vocabulary>, but you're also super lazy, so you call for your mom, yelling: "<reading>MAMEYYYYY</reading>, MAMMMEEYYY!" (<ja>まめ</ja>).

context_sentences.en: Beans, beans the magical fruit, the more you eat, the more you toot, the more you toot, the better you feel, so eat some beans at every meal.
context_sentences.ja: お豆さん、お豆さん、魔法の野菜。たくさん食べれば食べるほど、たくさん屁が出るぷっぷぷぷ。たくさんぷっぷぷ屁が出れば、気持ちが良くなるウッフフフ。だから毎食お豆を食べなさい。

data.meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Small</kanji> <kanji>bean</kanji>s refer to a type of bean known as <vocabulary>azuki bean</vocabulary>s. It will help if you've heard of this delicious popular bean, because there's not really anything effective we can do with the meaning mnemonic from this point on. Just know that small beans are azuki beans.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading doesn't make sense either. If you know that small beans are <vocabulary>azuki beans</vocabulary>, then you know that this is referring to a thing known as <reading>azuki</reading> (<ja>あずき</ja>). Other than that, there's not much else to do.

context_sentences.en: Azuki bean paste is made of azuki beans, but it’s pretty high in sugar.
context_sentences.ja: 餡こは小豆から作られているが、けっこう糖分が高い。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>supply</kanji> of <kanji>bean</kanji>s is when you take a bunch of beans, mash them up into a supply, and then ferment them all together to make them into <vocabulary>natto</vocabulary> (also known as <vocabulary>fermented soybeans</vocabulary>).
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is an exceptional one. <ja>豆</ja> is okay, and is the on'yomi reading from the kanji. The <ja>納</ja> part is weird though. Instead of being <ja>のう</ja> it's <ja>なっ</ja>. But, if you can remember the meaning of this word, you can just think about how you do <reading>not</reading> (<ja>なっとう</ja>) want to eat <vocabulary>natto</vocabulary>. At least a lot of people don't want to eat it. It's quite the acquired taste.

context_sentences.en: Don’t get me wrong. I love Japanese food, but I could never just eat natto alone.
context_sentences.ja: 誤解しないでね。日本料理は大好きなんだけど、納豆だけはどうしても食べられないの。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>rot</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to rot</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: Remember the word <ja>臭い</ja>, which means "stinky"? When something rots, it becomes stinky, and all <ja><reading>くさ</reading>い</ja>.

context_sentences.en: Don’t leave milk out of the fridge because it goes bad easily.
context_sentences.ja: 牛乳は腐りやすいんだから冷蔵庫の外に出しっ放しにしないでね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: When something <kanji>rot</kanji>s and <kanji>eat</kanji>s away at something, that is <vocabulary>corrosion</vocabulary>. Not a good thing.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: Stainless steel is supposed to withstand corrosion, isn’t it?
context_sentences.ja: ステンレスは腐食作用への耐久性があるんじゃなかったっけ？

data.meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Rot</kanji> and <kanji>failure</kanji> lead to <vocabulary>decomposition</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>rotting</vocabulary>. This word also has the related meaning of  <vocabulary>corruption</vocabulary>, similar to how "rotten" can mean "corrupt" in English.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: There was a smell of something decomposing in the air.
context_sentences.ja: そこには、何かが腐敗したような臭いがただよっていた。

context_sentences.en: This additive prevents food from rotting.
context_sentences.ja: この添加物により、食品の腐敗が防げます。

context_sentences.en: Many people are tired of the corrupt political ring.
context_sentences.ja: 多くの人々が腐敗した政治組織にうんざりしています。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, though it adds a few more meanings as well, like <vocabulary>nail</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>talon</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hoof</vocabulary> or really any hard thing on the ends of fingers or feet.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading takes the second <ja>爪</ja> reading, <ja><reading>つめ</reading></ja>.

context_sentences.en: Her right pinky nail is six meters long.
context_sentences.ja: 彼女の右の小指の爪の長さはなんと六メートルもあります。

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>cut</kanji> your <kanji>claw</kanji> you use a <vocabulary>nail clipper</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the reading you learned for the kanji <ja>爪</ja> and the word for the reading <ja>切る</ja>.

context_sentences.en: I was trying to clip my dog's nails but my mobile phone distracted me.
context_sentences.ja: 犬の爪を爪切りで切ってあげようとしてたんですけど、つい携帯に気を取られちゃいました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>carve</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to carve</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: <vocabulary>to carve</vocabulary> up the steak, you wish you could use a knife, but you don't have one. Instead, you'll have to use your <reading>keys</reading> (<ja>きざ</ja>) to cut it. Imagine trying to cut up the steak with these keys. It's very difficult.

context_sentences.en: I can’t be bothered to cut up the green onion.
context_sentences.ja: 葱を刻むのは面倒くさいよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Something that <kanji>carve</kanji>s out all the <kanji>time</kanji>s for something (say, on a big sign) and then <kanji>express</kanji>es them to the world, is a <vocabulary>timetable</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>schedule</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: The train schedule is a must-have for commuters.
context_sentences.ja: 通勤・通学者にとって、電車の時刻表は絶対に必要なものです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>deep</kanji> <kanji>carve</kanji> is very <vocabulary>serious</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>grave</vocabulary>. Just imagine getting cut with a sword. If the carve is deep, well, that's serious.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: It’s a serious problem that the number of Japanese children with thyroid abnormalities have been increasing.
context_sentences.ja: 甲状腺異常のある日本の子どもたちの数が増えているのは、深刻な問題です。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Another way to say <vocabulary>to shut</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to close</vocabulary>. A verb version of the kanji <ja>閉</ja>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is different from, say, <ja>閉める</ja> or <ja>しまる</ja>. Instead, the reading is <ja>とじる</ja>. Why? Because you shut your <reading>toe</reading> (<ja>と</ja>) in the door because it sheared off the hinges and was out of control.

context_sentences.en: She shut the laptop, stretched her arms, and yawned.
context_sentences.ja: 彼女はノートパソコンを閉じて、両腕を伸ばし、欠伸をした。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>muscle</kanji>, therefore it only does one thing. That's it. It is <vocabulary>single mindedly</vocabulary> doing that one thing. It is <vocabulary>intently</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>earnestly</vocabulary> doing that one thing.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is a bit weird. It's the kun'yomi readings, where <ja>一</ja> is <ja>ひと</ja> and <ja>筋</ja> is <ja>すじ</ja>. Look back on the vocab words that use these readings to remember this one.

context_sentences.en: Our oldest son does nothing but play baseball. He doesn’t have a girlfriend either.
context_sentences.ja: うちの長男は野球一筋なのよ。女っ気も無くてさ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: If <ja>垂らす</ja> is "to dangle something" then this is <vocabulary>to dangle</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to drip</vocabulary>. You're not doing the dangling, which is rare (<ja>れる</ja>), because usually it's you who's doing the dangling.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as <ja>垂らす</ja>.

context_sentences.en: It seems that the lid wasn't properly closed, so there's sauce leaking from one side.
context_sentences.ja: フタがちゃんと閉まっていなかったみたいで、横からソースが垂れている。

context_sentences.en: Last night the faucet broke, and the sound of dripping water bothered me so much I hardly got any sleep.
context_sentences.ja: 昨夜ジャグチが壊れて、水がポタポタ垂れる音が気になってほとんど寝られなかった。

context_sentences.en: Although Jazz's tail had been drooping the entire time his owner was out, the moment he heard Jiro's car, it sprang straight up and started wagging furiously.
context_sentences.ja: ジャズの尻尾は飼い主がいない間ずっと垂れ下がっていたが、次郎の車が聞こえた途端、ぴんとはね上がり、激しく振り始めた。

data.meaning_mnemonic: If <ja>宣言</ja> is a "proclamation," then the verb version will be <vocabulary>to proclaim</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: Don’t you think that the Japanese government should have declared a state of emergency at the time?
context_sentences.ja: あの時、日本政府は非常事態を宣言するべきだったと思わないかい。

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>盛る</ja> is "to heap up." If you "raise" (<ja>上げる</ja>) what you heap up, well, that comes with heaping something up, making this word <vocabulary>to heap up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to pile up</vocabulary>. This word is also used when you want <vocabulary>to liven up</vocabulary> some things. Heap up that energy and stir things up!
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>盛る</ja> and <ja>上げる</ja>. Know those words and you'll be able to read this one too.

context_sentences.en: My buddy is ridiculously interesting and he’s great at livening up parties.
context_sentences.ja: 俺の友達はメチャクチャ面白くて、パーティーを盛り上げるのが得意なんだよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Someone</kanji> who backstabs (<ja>裏切り</ja>) someone is a <vocabulary>traitor</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is <ja>裏切り</ja> and an exception reading for <ja>者</ja>. Just think about how you'd think of a traitor as a "thing" (<ja>物</ja>) and not a person.

context_sentences.en: He is not a traitor. He’s just naturally a little slow.
context_sentences.ja: 彼は裏切り者なんかじゃないよ。ただ、生まれつきちょっととぼけているだけさ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>various</kanji> <kanji>various</kanji> things. They are <vocabulary>various</vocabulary>. You have <vocabulary>all kinds of</vocabulary> them.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is a bit weird. Just think about how when you have various things, you probably have a lot of things. What do you want? You want <reading>more</reading> (<ja>もろ</ja>) of those things. <reading>More more</reading> more!

context_sentences.en: We decided to temporarily close our shop for a bunch of reasons.
context_sentences.ja: 諸々の理由がありまして、しばらく一時的に店を閉めることにしました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>編む</ja> is "to knit." When you knit in <kanji>three</kanji>s, you are knitting in a braid style. What do you braid? Hair. That makes this <vocabulary>braided hair</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the <ja>み</ja> from <ja>三つ</ja> and <ja>つ</ja> and <ja>編む</ja> combined into one (or should I say three?) braids. Just watch out because this isn't <ja>みっつあみ</ja>, it's just <ja>みつあみ</ja>. Listen to the audio a few times to make sure you remember how it's spelled and pronounced!

context_sentences.en: Oh come on, it was so obvious! There was no chemistry between you two! You definitely shouldn’t call that girl with the braided hair!
context_sentences.ja: おいおい、頼むよ。明らかにお前たちの相性全然よくなかっただろ！絶対にあの三つ編みの女に電話なんてしない方がいいって！

data.meaning_mnemonic: If <ja>閉める</ja> is "to shut" or "to close" this is going to be the version where you don't do anything and something shuts on its own. This word is <vocabulary>to be shut</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be closed</vocabulary>. You know this because you put your hand in the door to open it, but then it shuts (on its own) on your hand, <reading>marring</reading> (<ja>まる</ja>) your hand forever.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as <ja>閉める</ja>.

context_sentences.en: This lid doesn't close properly.
context_sentences.ja: このフタ、うまく閉まらないんだけど。

context_sentences.en: What time was it that the store closes?
context_sentences.ja: あのお店、何時に閉まるんだっけ？

context_sentences.en: Suddenly, the door shut by itself.
context_sentences.ja: 突然、扉がひとりでに閉まりました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>宝</ja> is a <kanji>treasure</kanji>. <ja>くじ</ja> is a lottery. So if you have a treasure lottery (you win treasure if you win the lottery) then you have yourself a <vocabulary>lottery</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading uses the <ja>宝</ja> vocab reading, <ja>たから</ja>.

context_sentences.en: "My little sister won the lottery." "Oh cool! How much?" "10,000 yen."
context_sentences.ja: 「妹が宝くじに当たったのよ。」「すごいね！で、いくら？」「一万円。」

context_sentences.en: It's wishful thinking, but I'll probably win the lottery at some point next year.
context_sentences.ja: きぼうてきかんそくでは、来年あたりに宝くじに当たるはずです。

context_sentences.en: My dad's secretary won the lottery, but I made a spelling mistake when I posted it on Facebook. Secretary was spelled secretly. It confused people and I got a lot of congrats.
context_sentences.ja: 父親の秘書が宝くじに当たったんだけど、それをフェイスブックに書いた時に秘書を秘密と書き間違えてしまい、みんなが勘違いしてたくさんおめでとうコメントを残してくれました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: If <ja>納める</ja> is "to supply" or "to deliver," then this word is when things have been delivered: so it's <vocabulary>to be satisfied</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be settled</vocabulary>. You aren't doing the supplying, and you know this because if you were to be caught supplying your reputation would be <reading>marr</reading>ed (<ja>まる</ja> for life).
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as <ja>納める</ja>.

context_sentences.en: I don't think they will be satisfied with just money.

data.meaning_mnemonic: I will <kanji>supply</kanji> and you will <kanji>acquire</kanji>. Does that sound good? Do I have your <vocabulary>consent</vocabulary>? I can see that you're <vocabulary>understanding</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>being convinced</vocabulary>. You're planning on <vocabulary>accepting</vocabulary> my proposition, aren't you?
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is a bit weird for <ja>納</ja>. Just imagine asking the consent question from the meaning, then have the other person say "<reading>Nahh!</reading> (<ja>なっ</ja>), no consent!"

context_sentences.en: I'm convinced by his opinion.

context_sentences.en: That I can't understand!

context_sentences.en: You made my daughter consent using money, didn’t you?
context_sentences.ja: どうせお前は娘を金ずくで納得させたんだろう？

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>否定</ja> is denial. Remember how <ja>形</ja> sometimes refers to grammar tense / type? Well, with a denial type grammar, you have a <vocabulary>negative form</vocabulary>, making it a <vocabulary>negative sentence</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If <ja>否定</ja> is "denial," then the verb version would be <vocabulary>to deny</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the word <ja>否定</ja> as well.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If <ja>尊敬</ja> is "respect" then the verb version would be <vocabulary>to respect</vocabulary>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>尊敬</ja> is respect. A respect <kanji>language</kanji> is <vocabulary>honorific Japanese</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>honorific language</vocabulary>, though usually this refers to Japanese).
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is <ja>尊敬</ja> plus <ja>語</ja> put together.

context_sentences.en: I often mix up honorific Japanese with humble Japanese.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If <ja>暮らす</ja> is "to live" or "to live one's life" then the noun version would be simply <vocabulary>life</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as <ja>暮らす</ja>.

context_sentences.en: Country life is boring.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have the <kanji>same</kanji> <kanji>sound</kanji> with a <vocabulary>different meaning</vocabulary> (<ja>異義</ja>), and it's a part of <kanji>language</kanji>. Same sounds... different meanings... that sounds like a <vocabulary>homophone</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>homonym</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. All I know is there's probably not a homonym for this word, for it is huge.

context_sentences.en: I was ashamed when I got zero on the homophone test.

context_sentences.en: I made a YouTube video about homonyms, so please take a look.

That's why it means <vocabulary>to rehash</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to bring up again</vocabulary>. You're bringing up memories from the past and steaming them up again.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>bright</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> isn't today (because today was terrible), it's <vocabulary>tomorrow</vocabulary>, because you can always look to tomorrow to be a better, brighter day.
data.reading_mnemonic:
The reading makes no sense at all. You have to learn it straight up, and can't rely on the kanji it's made from. Why is <vocabulary>tomorrow</vocabulary> going to be such a bright and awesome day? Because you're making <reading>ash ta</reading>cos for dinner, and that's your favorite. Imagine imagining tomorrow, full of ash tacos and deliciousness. Maybe you could use some of those Dorito taco shells?

A note about the other two readings <ja>あす</ja> and <ja>みょうにち</ja>: <ja>あす</ja> is used in the news and in weather reports, and <ja>みょうにち</ja> is really only used in business, so you should really only be using <ja>あした</ja> for now. But it's good to know that the other two readings exist!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji is <kanji>descend</kanji>, but this verb vocab word is <vocabulary>to get off</vocabulary>, as in, to get off the train, or to get out of the car. If you think about trains back in the day, you had to descend down to the platform to get out of them, which is how this word became what it is. You know that this word is the "to get off" word because once you get off the train, you enter the <reading>real</reading> (<ja>りる</ja>) world, where hardships are real and not as comfy as the train.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is unlike anything you've seen with this kanji. Just think about how you have <vocabulary>to get off</vocabulary> at <reading>O</reading>-station. None of the other letters are your stop. Just <reading>O</reading>-Station (<ja>お</ja>).

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>feeling</kanji> of <kanji>throw up</kanji> is <vocabulary>nausea</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>吐く</ja> and the (irregular) reading of <ja>気</ja> put together.

context_sentences.ja: ビールでいい気分になったんだけど、その後吐き気がひどくてさ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: If <ja>吐く</ja> is to throw up, and if <ja>出す</ja> is to remove or hand over, then if you throw up and hand that throw up over to someone via your throwing up, you are going <vocabulary>to spit out</vocabulary> at them, or <vocabulary>to spew out</vocabulary>, or something gross along those lines. Then again, this word can be used to be like "spit the info out already!" too, so it's not all spitting for reals.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>吐く</ja> and <ja>出す</ja>.

context_sentences.en: The man spit out the candy he’d been sucking.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If a <ja>奴</ja> is just some dude or some guy, adding a <ja>ら</ja> on there makes it plural. Now it's <vocabulary>those dudes</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>those guys</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>奴</ja>.

context_sentences.en: Those guys are bathing and relaxing in the sun while we are working.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>mouth</kanji> <kanji>deep red</kanji> is a deep red you put on your mouth. This is <vocabulary>lipstick</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings of both. <ja>口</ja> and <ja>紅</ja> vocab words combined into one.

context_sentences.en: I left my lipstick in my pocket and it melted in the dryer.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If <ja>薦める</ja> is "to recommend," then the noun version would be a <vocabulary>recommendation</vocabulary> or some <vocabulary>advice</vocabulary>. This generally refers to a recommendation of a person or thing, not an action.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>薦める</ja>. Might I make the <vocabulary>recommendation</vocabulary> to learn that word first?

context_sentences.en: Those slippers are my recommendation.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If <ja>勤める</ja> is "to be employed at," then the noun version of this is <vocabulary>work</vocabulary>. I mean, I really hope you're doing work at the place that employed you... if not you'll probably be fired.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <ja>磁場</ja> is a "magnetic field." An <kanji>electricity</kanji> version of this is an <vocabulary>electromagnetic field</vocabulary>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>放射</ja> is "radiation." Add the <kanji>ability</kanji> of radiation and you have <vocabulary>radioactivity</vocabulary>, for some reason. I guess things don't have radioactivity until you have given them the ability of radiation, right?

context_sentences.en: Sorry to ask for your consent after the decision was made.
context_sentences.ja: 事後承諾になってしまってすみません。

context_sentences.en: Still no word from him on his acceptance?
context_sentences.ja: 彼からの承諾の返事はまだないのか？

context_sentences.en: My father agreed to our marriage without hesitation.
context_sentences.ja: 父は、私達の結婚を二つ返事で承諾した。

data.meaning_mnemonic: I will <kanji>accept</kanji> and I have <kanji>agreement</kanji> in the matter. I have come to <vocabulary>acceptance</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: Koichi reluctantly agreed to become the president of the United States.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチはアメリカ合衆国の大統領になることを渋々受諾した。

data.meaning_mnemonic: I will <kanji>permit</kanji> this, and you have my <kanji>agreement</kanji>. Both of these things combine to be my <vocabulary>permission</vocabulary> and my <vocabulary>consent</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: Please obtain permission from the manager beforehand.
context_sentences.ja: 予め管理人の許諾を得てください。

context_sentences.en: I got the permission from the person in the video before releasing it.
context_sentences.ja: このビデオを公開することは、本人の許諾済みです。

context_sentences.en: If you allow me to marry your daughter, I’ll give you my consent to use our company’s trademark.
context_sentences.ja: もし娘さんとの結婚を許可してくださるのなら、あなたに我が社の登録商標の使用を許諾します。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Do we have <kanji>agreement</kanji> or <kanji>no</kanji>? Which is it? <vocabulary>consent or refusal</vocabulary>? <vocabulary>Yes or no</vocabulary>? Choose!
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: "Please let us know whether this is acceptable or not" is a common phrase used in business letters and emails.
context_sentences.ja: 「諾否を御一報ください」という言葉は、仕事の手紙やEmailなどでよく使われるフレーズです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>elephant</kanji> <kanji>tusk</kanji> is the material known as <vocabulary>ivory</vocabulary> (or just an <vocabulary>elephant tusk</vocabulary>).
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: I switched out my name stamp for an expensive ivory one.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Using your animal <vocabulary>fang</vocabulary> you are able to eat <reading>kibble</reading> (<ja>きば</ja>).

context_sentences.en: Our stock of fake fangs for Halloween is running out.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>降参</ja> is "surrender" so the verb version would be <vocabulary>to surrender</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading is the same as <ja>降参</ja> as well, of course.

context_sentences.en: Haven’t you ever thought about surrendering, even once?
context_sentences.ja: 降参しようと思ったことは今まで一度もないんですか。

data.meaning_mnemonic: If <ja>暮らす</ja> is "to live" or "to live one's life," then to live one's life as <ja>一人</ja>, means you are <vocabulary>living alone</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the vocab readings from <ja>一人</ja> and <ja>暮らす</ja>.

context_sentences.en: I’m living alone and I forgot to set my clock back an hour when the winter time started.
context_sentences.ja: 一人暮らしをしているので、冬時間が始まった時に、時計を一時間遅らせることを忘れてしまいました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>he</kanji> <kanji>woman</kanji> is <vocabulary>she</vocabulary>. Also could mean <vocabulary>girlfriend</vocabulary>, depending on how it's used.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading for this is a bit weird, at least for the <ja>彼</ja> portion. Just think about how <vocabulary>she</vocabulary> (your <vocabulary>girlfriend</vocabulary>) is a <reading>canoe</reading> (<ja>かの</ja>), and you love that canoe girlfriend more than anything. She is your best friend and your lover, and everyone thinks you're weird. Imagine everyone thinking you're weird as you give kisses to your canoe girlfriend.

context_sentences.en: She has good taste in clothes, but she doesn’t have the best figure.
context_sentences.ja: 彼女は服のセンスはいいが、体型がいまいちだ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>恥</ja> is a "disgrace." If you <ja>知らず</ja> then you don't know something. In this case, you don't know disgrace, and a person who doesn't know disgrace is a <vocabulary>shameless person</vocabulary>, because they don't care what disgraces them and what doesn't.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is <ja>恥</ja> and <ja>知る</ja> put together.

context_sentences.en: My brother is such a shameless liar. He told me he had no idea what happened, but he was the one who ate all my bacon.
context_sentences.ja: あの俺の兄貴は恥知らずの嘘つきだ。何の事だかサッパリ分からないなんて言ってたくせに、俺のベーコンを平らげたのはアイツだったんだよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: An "examination hell" is the nickname given to the exams you have to take in Japan all at once. That's why this is <vocabulary>exam hell</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that smooshes two previous vocabulary words together into a new one. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: Studying on the train is common for Japanese students who suffer from exam hell.
context_sentences.ja: 試験地獄に苦しむ日本の学生にとっては、電車で勉強するのは当たり前のことです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you're <kanji>boat</kanji> <kanji>drunk</kanji> you have <vocabulary>sea sickness</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading for <ja>船</ja> goes to <ja>ふな</ja> (probably because you're sick and can't spell). The <ja>酔い</ja> comes from <ja>酔う</ja>.

context_sentences.en: I got over my seasickness with this medicine.
context_sentences.ja: この薬で船酔いを克服しました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A ____<kanji>pot</kanji> is any kind of food that's made inside the pot, put together, and cooked. This refers to a type of <vocabulary>pot</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>stew</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hotpot</vocabulary>, and is attached onto the names of said pots, stews, and hotpots.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: Have you ever tried soy milk hotpot?
context_sentences.ja: 豆乳鍋を食べてみたことはありますか？

data.meaning_mnemonic: If <ja>払う</ja> is "to pay" then the noun version is a <vocabulary>payment</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>払う</ja>, so know that and it will pay forward your knowledge to this one.

context_sentences.en: We offer 5% off if you pay with cash.
context_sentences.ja: 現金払いにして頂けるなら、5%引きにさせて頂きます。

data.meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>oil</kanji> <kanji>painting</kanji> is an <vocabulary>oil painting</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi for <ja>油</ja> (which you learned with the vocabulary) and the on'yomi for <ja>絵</ja> (which you learned with the kanji).

context_sentences.en: I bought this oil painting for 1500 yen at a flea market.
context_sentences.ja: この油絵はフリマで千五百円で買ったんですよ。

context_sentences.en: My grandmother used to collect oil paintings.
context_sentences.ja: 祖母は油絵を集めていた。

context_sentences.en: What's the most famous brand of oil paints?
context_sentences.ja: 油絵用の絵の具で有名なブランドは？

data.meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Sweet</kanji> <kanji>vinegar</kanji> is <vocabulary>sweet vinegar</vocabulary>. Them Japanese love their sweet things.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is <ja>甘い</ja> plus <ja>酢</ja>, combined together. It's the kun'yomi readings, but that's probably because we're combing two words into one. It also changes the <ja>す</ja> to <ja>ず</ja> so, remember that.

context_sentences.en: During lunch the other day for some reason one of the students pulled a bottle of sweet vinegar out of her desk.
context_sentences.ja: この間、給食の時に生徒が何故か机の中から甘酢の瓶を取り出したのよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>盛り上げる</ja> is "to heap up" - this has a similar idea, except now this is more like an excitement or swelling. As excitement heaps up in you, you are going <vocabulary>to get excited</vocabulary>. Note how <ja>上がる</ja> is in here. This means something is happening to you (or something else), but you're not doing the action. When you get all sorts of excitement building up in you, you aren't really doing it, it's just happening on its own in reaction to something else.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>盛り</ja> and <ja>上がる</ja>. Let the excitement build as you realize you know the reading already.

context_sentences.en: Kids can take the most mundane, random things and get so excited.
context_sentences.ja: 子どもっていうのは、どんなささいなことでも手当たり次第に盛り上がることができるのよね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <ja>い</ja> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>slow</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>slow</vocabulary> (or, if you're slow, you're probably <vocabulary>late</vocabulary>, too).
data.reading_mnemonic: How <vocabulary>slow</vocabulary> are you? You are <reading>oh so</reading> slow (<ja>おそ</ja>).

context_sentences.en: My computer is very slow because it’s running out of hard drive space.
context_sentences.ja: 私のパソコンはハードディスクの容量が無くなってきているので、動作がすごく遅いです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>恥ずかしい</ja> is "embarrassing." This is the verb version. What happens when someone is embarrassed? They become shy and bashful. That's why this word is <vocabulary>to be shy</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be bashful</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>恥ずかしい</ja>.

context_sentences.en: Although she was determined to become a stripper, she’s still shy about dancing naked in public.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If <ja>破る</ja> is "to tear" or "to rip," then this is <vocabulary>to get torn</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to get broken</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to get ripped</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>破る</ja>.

context_sentences.en: Why do my pants always start wearing out in the butt area first?

data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Helps that I introduced introduction to you earlier.

context_sentences.en: It’s hard to choose which girl to introduce to you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember how a <ja>年賀状</ja> is a new year's card? This is another kind of card/letter, but this time it's for an introduction (<ja>紹介</ja>), making it a <vocabulary>letter of introduction</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know <ja>紹介</ja> as well.

context_sentences.en: You need a referral letter from a doctor to make an appointment at this hospital.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>soup</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji> is what you use to refer to <vocabulary>soups</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is both the kun'yomi readings combined to form one word. So, you'll want to make sure you know the word <ja>汁</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>味噌</ja> is "miso," and that <ja>汁</ja> is "soup." So, combine them together and you have <vocabulary>Miso Soup</vocabulary>.

context_sentences.en: "We have to finish eating this miso soup by tomorrow." "Okay, let’s get it over with."

data.meaning_mnemonic: Time to <kanji>pay</kanji> over your <kanji>drunk</kanji>edness. You try, but you can't pay over drunkedness. You must be super <vocabulary>drunk</vocabulary> to think that.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a combination of <ja>酔う</ja> and <ja>払い</ja>, put together with some small <ja>っ</ja> and a rendaku added in because you're drunk.

context_sentences.en: My heart was pounding while I was hassled by a drunk last night.

data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is <ja>二日</ja> and <ja>酔い</ja> put together (the reading for that comes from <ja>酔う</ja>).

context_sentences.en: I’m hungover and I also have a cramp in my leg. Today is the worst.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>fueling</kanji> (<ja>給油</ja>) <kanji>place</kanji> is a place where you get things fueled. This can either be a <vocabulary>gas station</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>filling station</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hop</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to hop</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to jump</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to leap</vocabulary>. Basically anything that gets both feet off the ground via your own foot propulsion.
data.reading_mnemonic: Know how <ja>飛ぶ</ja> means "to fly"? This is a similar idea, though this time you're not flying nearly as much, because you're just hopping or jumping. Anyways, the readings are the same.

context_sentences.en: She performed a perfect triple axel, but her score wasn’t very good.
context_sentences.ja: 彼女は完璧なトリプルアクセルを跳んだのに、スコアはあまり伸びなかった。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>shining</kanji> <kanji>peace</kanji> time was a time known as the <vocabulary>Showa Era</vocabulary>. This can also refer to the <vocabulary>Showa Emperor</vocabulary> or just <vocabulary>Showa</vocabulary> itself. Everything Showa is here.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: Which year of Showa were you born in?

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>fishing</kanji> <kanji>expert</kanji> is a <vocabulary>fisherman</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading is the <ja>りょう</ja> reading, because you gotta get in your row boat to be a <vocabulary>fisherman</vocabulary>.

context_sentences.en: I know that fisherman because he is my brother in law.
context_sentences.ja: 私はその漁師を知っていますよ。私の義理の兄ですから。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>fishing</kanji> <kanji>boat</kanji> is a <vocabulary>fishing boat</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: I had my fishing boat stolen last night.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>fishing</kanji> <kanji>industry</kanji> is the <vocabulary>fishing industry</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>fishery</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: This is a small fishing village and most of the people living here are engaged in fishing.
context_sentences.ja: ここは小さな漁村で、ここに住むほとんどの人は漁業に従事しています。

data.meaning_mnemonic: To make <kanji>reparation</kanji>s is <vocabulary>to compensate for</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to make up for</vocabulary> something. You're going <vocabulary>to atone for</vocabulary> your sins.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you try <vocabulary>to compensate for</vocabulary> everything you've ever done wrong, you become too good for your own britches. You are <reading>too good now</reading> (<ja>つぐなう</ja>).

context_sentences.en: How can we compensate you for it? Choose between cash, prepaid cards, or gift certificates.
context_sentences.ja: どうやってお償いいたしましょうか。現金、プリペイドカード、商品券の中から選んでください。

context_sentences.en: Even if you atoned for your sins with your own death, it wouldn’t solve the problem.
context_sentences.ja: たとえあなたが死をもって罪を償っても、問題は解決しないでしょう。

context_sentences.en: I got so tired of making up for past mistakes.
context_sentences.ja: 過去の過ちを償うことに、疲れちゃったんだよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: My <kanji>dialect</kanji> has offended you? I will make <kanji>reparation</kanji> by giving you a <vocabulary>reimbursement</vocabulary> and some <vocabulary>compensation</vocabulary>. I'm sorry my dialect was so bad you couldn't understand the speech. Here's your money back.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: I ripped a fisherman’s nets by mistake while taking pictures, so I had to reimburse him.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>punish</kanji> <kanji>task</kanji> <kanji>place</kanji> is the place you go to do your task of punishment. It is a <vocabulary>jail</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>prison</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: This prison is full at the moment, so we’ll put you on the waiting list.
context_sentences.ja: この刑務所は今満員なので、キャンセル待ちとさせて頂きますね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>death</kanji> <kanji>punish</kanji>ment is the <vocabulary>death penalty</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: The execution was delayed for five hours.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>punish</kanji> <kanji>action</kanji> is when someone goes out to try to find people who do bad things, so that they can be punished. The people who do this are people like a <vocabulary>police detective</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>detective</vocabulary>).
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: Without warning that officer grabbed my girlfriend’s arm and kissed her. So I punched him and he arrested me. It’s unfair.
context_sentences.ja: その刑事は俺の彼女の腕を突然掴んで、彼女にキスをしたんだ。だから、俺はそいつを殴りつけてやったんだけど、そしたら逮捕されたんだよ。そんなの不公平だよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>punish</kanji> <kanji>period of time</kanji> is the time in which you are being punished in prison. This is your <vocabulary>prison term</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: The convict was released after serving a fifteen-year prison term, but he had nowhere to go.
context_sentences.ja: その囚人は、十五年間の刑期を務めた後で釈放されたが、行く当てがなかった。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>punish</kanji> <kanji>penalty</kanji> is a <vocabulary>punishment</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: In order to root out crime, I think we should restore all the brutal punishments, like burning people at the stake.
context_sentences.ja: 犯罪を根絶するには、火あぶりの刑みたいな残酷な刑罰を全部復活させるべきだと思うね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Until the <kanji>end</kanji> of <kanji>somebody</kanji>, you will be <kanji>punish</kanji>ed. If you are punished to your end, you are being given a <vocabulary>life sentence</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: This is the first time I’ve been given a life sentence.
context_sentences.ja: 終身刑を言い渡されたのは初めてです。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji is <kanji>recruit</kanji> so the verb vocab version would, you'd think, be 'to recruit,' but it's <vocabulary>to appeal for something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to invite something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to raise something</vocabulary>. So, it's kind of like recruiting, but instead of people, you're recruiting for things and actions.

This verb can also be intransitive (oh my!) and mean <vocabulary>to grow violent</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to become stronger</vocabulary>. It's like all of that recruiting is happening inside of you and causing some weird things to happen to you!

data.meaning_mnemonic: To <ja>及ぶ</ja> is "to reach" or "to amount to." The noun version is more like a grammar thing, as it means "<vocabulary>as well as</vocabulary>." Perhaps if you are reaching a certain point or certain amount, then you are adding things on. That's why "as well as" is the meaning of this one.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>及ぶ</ja>, so if you know that one you know that one <vocabulary>as well as</vocabulary> this one.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>ultra</kanji> or <kanji>super</kanji> so the verb version is what happens when you do something ultra or super much. You start <vocabulary>to exceed</vocabulary> the amount you were meant to do it. If you ultra drive a car, you exceed the speed limit. If you ultra study, you exceed your brain capacity. Get it?

data.meaning_mnemonic: You'd think that this means "to bullet" but it does not. It means <vocabulary>to play a stringed instrument</vocabulary>. It's actually used for all stringed instruments, and all instruments with a keyboard, like pianos and electric keyboards. Just imagine taking a bullet and using it as a pick for a guitar, then using it to press down the keys of a piano and play a tune.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as <ja>引く</ja>, which is "to pull." When you play a stringed instrument, you are pulling the string in a direction to make it vibrate and create a sound. So, "to pull" and "to play a stringed instrument" share a reading. It's a bit more of a stretch for instruments with keyboards, but pianos do at least have strings...

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>recommend</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to recommend</vocabulary>.

This word is almost the same as <ja>薦める</ja>, but they're both common so I recommend you learn them both. The subtle difference is that <ja>薦める</ja> contains the positive nuance of recommending things, actions, and people because of their charms and/or merits, whereas <ja>勧める</ja> is used when recommending someone take a certain action without necessarily referring to a reason. <ja>勧める</ja> can also be used when encouraging someone to do something by trying to cheer them up or praise them, or when offering someone something, like a drink.
data.reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as <ja>薦める</ja>, since they mean almost the same thing.

It's a word you'll see a lot to varying degrees of kanji and length.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>review</kanji>. What do you do when you review something? You look back on it. Meaning <vocabulary>to look back on something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to reflect on something</vocabulary>. This can also mean <vocabulary>to be attentive to someone</vocabulary>, for example your family.

This is a transitive verb, meaning it takes a direct object. You look back on the past, you reflect on the consequences of your actions, and you're attentive to your family.
data.reading_mnemonic: For the reading, think about another word that is similar: <ja>帰る</ja>. With <ja>帰る</ja> you are returning to somewhere. With this word, you're returning to look back on something. They share the same first part reading, so you should take advantage of that. <ja>帰る</ja> → <ja>かえり</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji means <ja>milord</ja>, and this word used to be a name ender similar to the English title <vocabulary>Lord</vocabulary>, but nowadays it's closer to <vocabulary>Mr.</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>Ms.</vocabulary>. It's rarely used in speaking or even written correspondence these days, but is still used in official documents, and you'll probably see it most on certificates. If in doubt, you're better off choosing the name ender <ja>様</ja> because it's much more widely used, and also more polite than <ja>殿</ja>.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:

Do you know a <vocabulary>Lord</vocabulary>? Imagine it being someone named <vocabulary>Mr.</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>Ms.</vocabulary> <reading>Don</reading> (<ja>どの</ja>). If you know a Don, that's great, imagine that person. If you don't, think of a famous Don that's out there.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Milord</kanji> (you say very formally with a <kanji>formal name title</kanji>). You say it very formally because this person is a lord, or more specifically, a <vocabulary>feudal lord</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for <ja>殿</ja> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>Feudal Lord</vocabulary>s were pretty brutal back in the day. If you did something wrong he'd get to punish you. What kind of punishment? Well, he'd cut off your toe! That left most people yelling, "My <reading>toe?! NO</reading>!" (<ja>との</ja>). Imagine screaming "Toe no!" over and over as the feudal lord got closer and closer. Holding a pair of hedge clippers or something. Maybe if you yell "toe no" enough times, he'll change his mind.

data.reading_mnemonic: What is multiplying? Your use of the word "<reading>fu</reading>" (<ja>ふ</ja>) for when you laugh. You used to say just "ha ha ha" like everyone else. Now the occurrences of you saying <reading>fufufu</reading> is really multiplying. You might also notice that this is similar to the word <ja>増える</ja>, which means "to increase." This has a similar meaning and the same reading, use that to your advantage!
